title: 108_hr3748
content: The "Health Care Cost Integrity and Fairness Act of 2004" is based on Congress's constitutional authority to regulate commerce. It introduces a refundable and advanceable credit for health insurance costs under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The "Health Care Cost Integrity and Fairness Act of 2004" introduces a tax credit for qualified health insurance paid by individuals, limited to monthly amounts based on the number of individuals covered. The "Health Care Cost Integrity and Fairness Act of 2004" offers a tax credit for qualified health insurance payments based on the number of individuals covered. Qualified health insurance is defined as insurance meeting specific requirements. The section 223(c)(2)(A)(ii) ensures that there are no exclusions or limitations on coverage for preexisting medical conditions for applicants who have been continuously insured for at least 1 year under specific health insurance programs. The United States Code specifies that applicants who have not been continuously insured for at least 1 year may have limitations on coverage for preexisting medical conditions, with the exclusion period not exceeding the time since the condition was first diagnosed. The United States Code specifies limitations on coverage for preexisting medical conditions for applicants not continuously insured for at least 1 year, with the exclusion period not exceeding the time since the condition was first diagnosed. Exclusions apply to certain insurance plans, and a transition rule for 2004 mandates coverage without limitations for preexisting conditions. Special rules coordinate insurance payments with medical deductions. The taxpayer's insurance payments are not considered for tax credits or deductions under specific sections. Credits are denied to dependents if a deduction is allowed to another taxpayer. Married couples must file a joint return to claim the credit. Married couples must file a joint return to claim the credit for qualified health insurance coverage. Verification of coverage and amount paid is required, and the credit amount is reduced by any advance payments made on behalf of the taxpayer. The aggregate amount paid on behalf of the taxpayer under section 7528 for months in the taxable year is subject to a cost-of-living adjustment. Dollar amounts in subsection (b)(1)(B) are increased based on the cost-of-living adjustment for the calendar year. Additionally, there is a provision for the advance payment of the credit in Chapter 77 of the Code. The tax code is amended to include a new section regarding miscellaneous provisions. "SEC. 7528. ADVANCE PAYMENT OF CREDIT FOR HEALTH INSURANCE COSTS." The Secretary will establish a program to make payments for qualified health insurance on behalf of individuals, with limitations on the total amount per individual per taxable year. Conforming amendments are made to related sections of the Internal Revenue Code. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to update section 36 and add new items. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to update section 36 and add new items related to health insurance costs and overpayments of tax. A new item, Sec. 7528, is added for advance payment of credit for health insurance costs. These amendments apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 2003.
